column4:
Above

,

Up

,

Over
column6:
You find a toe on the ground. It's weird, because it's above the ground, not where toes belong.

- Hint: Focus your imagination on how body parts should be buried, not above ground like this. Sure, finding a toe is a little strange, but finding a toe above the ground? Downright silly.

column4:
Below

,

Down

,

Under

,

Beneath
column6:
There's a toe below ground.

- Hint: So, where is the toe now? It's below ground. Imagine yourself digging it out, and thinking... ugh, why does it have to be below ground like this? So irritating. Will I be able to sew it back on in time to save it?

The big radical and the big kanji are exactly the same!

- Hint: So, if you know the radical, you know the meaning of this kanji as well.

The construction radical and the construction kanji are the same!

This kanji also means industry, which is what construction is, if you think about it. It's all part of the construction industry.

- Hint: Know your radicals and you'll know this kanji's meaning.

This isn't exactly the same as the fins radical, but it's close. Sometimes this will happen (where we have to use a slightly "modified radical" version of the original), so it's good to understand that now, early on. In this case, we have fins. How many fins? Eight fins. How do you know that? Because you caught four fish with two fins each.

- Hint: Count the fins out in front of you, all the way from one to eight. It'll help if you actually do this. Now smell each fin, and think "Wow, I have to smell all eight of these?" Yes, you do.

The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for enter first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means enter as well.

- Hint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!

The mountain radical and the mountain kanji are the same.

- Hint: Make sure you're studying your radicals. If you are, then you're studying your kanji as well!

The mouth radical and the mouth kanji are exactly the same!

- Hint: If you learned your radicals–which the WaniKani system forces you to do (unless you're cheating)–you'll already know the meaning of the kanji.

Nice! This kanji is the same as the radical that looks just like it (down to the meaning, even!). The radical is nine and the kanji is nine, making the meaning of this kanji really easy to remember as long as you know the radical first.

- Hint: If you know your radicals well, this kanji will be a breeze!

Lying on the ground is something that looks just like the ground, the number One. Why is this One lying down? It's been shot by the number two. It's lying there, bleeding out and dying. The number One doesn't have long to live.

- Hint: To remember the meaning of One, imagine yourself there at the scene of the crime. You grab One in your arms, trying to prop it up, trying to hear its last words. Instead, it just splatters some blood on your face. "Who did this to you?" you ask. The number One points weakly, and you see number Two running off into an alleyway. He's always been jealous of number One and knows he can be number one now that he's taken the real number one out.

Remember how the radical version of this kanji meant person because it's a person walking from the side with their arms down? Well this is a person too!

- Hint: Know the radicals, and you shall know the kanji.

The radical and the meaning of this kanji are the same. Both are Power.

- Hint: If you know the radicals, you should be feeling fine... No, you should feel powerful!

The river radical and the river kanji are the same as each other!

- Hint: So, if you know the radical you know the kanji as well.

Lucky for you (as is the case with many of the lower-stroke kanji), this kanji is the same as the radical you've already learned. The radical that makes up this kanji is seven and the kanji (which is exactly the same) is also seven. So, if you know the radical, you know the meaning of the kanji as well.

- Hint: Make sure you know your radicals well and you'll be A-Okay on this one!

This cross is the symbol for the number ten. A good way to remember this is to think about all the religions that have crosses and also important sets of tens.

- Hint: If you're familiar with Christianity, they have a cross and ten commandments. Cross = ten, you see?

This kanji is made up of the ground radical (which also happens to be the kanji for "one") and the radical for two. Combine one and two together and what do you get? Three!

- Hint: This one should be pretty self explanatory! Even easier, you can look at this kanji and see it has three straight lines. You know what one looks like. You know what two looks like. So... this is three!

The kanji two and the radical two are the exact same things. Therefore, you know the kanji for two already!

- Hint: More simply put, you can just know that this kanji is the double of One. It's two lines, that's not all that hard to remember!

The radical for woman and the kanji for woman are exactly the same.

- Hint: That means if you know your radicals well, you know the meaning of this kanji as well! How swell.

You're sitting on your stool again!!?

- Hint: Imagine your super comfy, state-of-the-art stool. You take it everywhere with you, and you're always sitting on it. Again, and again, and again. You love that stool.

The king has something in his hand that he's dropping... but it bounces too! He's bouncing a ball

- Hint: This kanji looks just like a king bouncing a ball, no? If not, imagine the kanji itself bouncing the drop (the ball) over and over again, then laying some hoops like a pro.

column4:
Book

,

Origin

,

Real

,

Main
column6:
The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for book first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means book as well.

Take note that the second, third, and fourth meanings of this kanji are origin, real, and main. You can figure this out by thinking about how books mainly have their origins in real life.

- Hint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo! And good luck with all the meanings (sorry sorry sorry).

The child radical and the child kanji are exactly the same.

- Hint: So, if you know your radicals, you know your kanji as well! This won't last forever (where radicals are exactly the same as the kanji) so enjoy it while the kanji are still small and simple!

column4:
Circle

,

Circular

,

Round
column6:
What's something with nine sides? Just add a drop and you'll have something that's almost a circle.

- Hint: It's not quite a circle though. You just need to add a drop of liquid to the edges to smooth it out to become a full circle.

There is a line on the ground so you stop and a giant sign pops up that says CORRECT! You obeyed the rules of the road and did the correct thing.

- Hint: Imagine walking, staring at the ground until you come across a line that you're supposed to stop at. If you stop, the big "correct" sign appears, chiming a happy tune.

column4:
Dirt

,

Soil

,

Earth

,

Ground
column6:
The dirt radical and the dirt kanji are the same!

- Hint: As long as you know the radical dirt, you know the kanji dirt.

The dog radical and dog kanji are exactly the same!

- Hint: Soon there will be very few kanji/radical-same combos ... so enjoy it while you can.

The evening radical and the evening kanji are the same. If you know the radical you know the meaning of the kanji.

- Hint: Do what you're meant to do. Study those radicals!

There are two mountains in front of you... and probably a bunch more around you too. You are in a pass, and don't know how to get out. You are frantically looking for the exit before you freeze to death. The most important thing is to find the exit from this mountain range - your life depends on it.

- Hint: In your imagination, really feel like your life depends on getting out. The important part is the feeling of "needing to get out of the mountain pass." If you have this feeling, you'll be more likely to remember that this kanji means exit, because that's what you want to do when you see this kanji.

The eye radical and eye kanji are the same as each other, so now you know them both.

- Hint: Well... you'll know them both as long as you studied your radicals, young grasshopper. If you didn't, then you're just a young grasshopper who needs to study their radicals.

column4:
Finish

,

Complete

,

End
column6:
Think about it this way. There is a famous fishing lure inventor, working on his best work ever. He’s old, and he’s been trying to make the best fishing lure for the last 50 years, and knows this will be his last invention. Then he figures it out. He takes one barb, and connects the end of it to the top of another barb. When he does this, he knows his work is finally finished.

- Hint: Make sure you look at this amazing fishing lure too - hold it in your hand, see the two barbs fused together. Think about how strange this lure is. Is this really the best in the world? Will this really finish all other fishing lures?

The fire radical and the fire kanji are the same as each other.

- Hint: If you know the radicals then this one is EZPZ.

The five radical and the five kanji are the same.

- Hint: Know your radicals, friend-o.

Imagine contorting yourself in such a way that your legs end up inside your mouth. You have bent your body in all the wrong ways in order to achieve this. In fact, if you look at yourself, you look like a square now... You're just a person with four sides.

- Hint: If you can get to square, you should be able to get to four as well, since squares always have four sides.

On the ground you put barbs at the bottom of a slide because you're a genius trying to catch another genius.

- Hint: Imagine yourself placing the barbs in front of the slide, thinking about how your genius plan will surely catch another genius.

The hand radical and the hand kanji are identical in looks and meaning! That should make things easy!

- Hint: Make sure you're studying your radicals. It won't be forever that radicals and kanji overlap so nicely like this!

The radical heaven is the same as the kanji heaven, making this an easy kanji to memorize.

- Hint: If you know your radicals well (and you should!) you know the meaning of this kanji well, as well!

The king radical and the king kanji are the same!

- Hint: Hopefully you're a king of radicals... because if you are, this kanji was super easy for you!

Narwhals do construction with their left hands (or flippers, I guess). That's because all narwhals are left-handed!

- Hint: Picture a bunch of narwhals constructing an underwater ice village. They're all working away with their left hands.

column4:
Middle

,

In

,

Inside

,

Center
column6:
The radical Middle and the kanji Middle are both the same. So if you know one, you know the other.

- Hint: Make sure you're studying your radicals, otherwise you might find yourself in the middle of a kanji-learning problem.

The moon kanji is made up of the moon radical.

- Hint: This should be EZPZ as long as you know the radicals already!

column4:
Repeater

,

Repetition

,

Reduplication

,

Iteration Mark
column6:
This is a strange kanji because it doesn't really mean anything at all. In fact, what it does is it repeats the kanji that comes before it. For example: 人々 is actually 人人. This kanji shows up whenever there's a repeating kanji, because it's often easier to write than writing a more complicated kanji twice. That's why this kanji is the repeater. It repeats what comes before it.

To remember that this kanji is the repeater, though, think of a drop of water dripping into a prison. Drip drop drip drop. It does that over and over again, driving the prisoners nuts. But it never stops. It just repeats over and over.

- Hint: Since this kanji doesn't really have a meaning as much as it does a function, try to change the way you think about it when you're memorizing it.

column4:
Rice Paddy

,

Rice Field

,

Field
column6:
The rice paddy radical and the rice paddy kanji are the same, making this one super easy to remember, at least meaning-wise.

- Hint: Just know your radicals, and you will know your kanji as well.

Narwhal mouths are on the right side of their head. In fact, some people didn't think they had mouths at all because they weren't looking from the right. Rookie mistake.

- Hint: Imagine looking at a narwhal from the front. No mouth. Now look at it from the right. Mouth!

Just imagine a beast with a lid for a head and fins for feet, running around looking as insane as possible (really imagine it!). When it runs up to you, it shows you the top of its lid-head. On it is written the numbers 666. Why? Because it's a spawn of the devil, and the number six is the devil's number.

- Hint: Imagine this beast doing various crazy things, the crazier the better (to help you remember). Make sure all these things are associated with the devil and the devil's number (six), so you can remember the meaning of this kanji.

The small radical and the small kanji are exactly the same.

- Hint: Knowing radicals sure is nice, huh?

The radical stand and the kanji stand are the same thing, so now you know them both.

- Hint: If you're keeping up with your radical studies, you're also keeping up with your kanji studies!

The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both street.

- Hint: As long as you know the radical street, you know the kanji street.

The sun radical and sun kanji are the same, huzzah! Also, if you want to remember day as well, you can just think about how a day is the time it takes for the sun to cross the sky.

- Hint: The radical for this one is easy too, making the meaning for this kanji super easy as well!

The radical and the meaning of this kanji are almost the same! The radical is sword, but we're learning Japanese, so can you name a Japanese sword? That's right, the most common is a katana, which happens to be the meaning of this kanji as well.

- Hint: The progression on this one is important. When you think "sword" you have to think, "What kinds of swords do Japanese people have?" Then you'll reach the meaning of this kanji on your own.

This kanji looks like and means the same thing as the radical, which makes it particularly easy to remember.

- Hint: As long as you know the radical thousand then you know the kanji thousand as well!

This is another kanji that is the same as the radical. Both tree and tree are the same in looks and meaning.

- Hint: So, how are those radicals doing? Do you know them well?

The water radical and the water kanji are the same.

- Hint: So as long as you know the radicals, you know the kanji.

The radical white and the kanji white are the same.

- Hint: Study your radicals hard! Most important thing!

The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for writing first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means writing as well.

- Hint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!

column4:
Yen

,

Round

,

Circle
column6:
The combination of radicals for this kanji may not be obvious at first, but if you look carefully you'll see it. The lid is inside the head for this kanji because it's holding something in. Imagine the top of someone's head being closed by a lid. Open that lid up and peer inside... it's full of yen coins, the currency of Japan!

- Hint: Another thing that will help is to associate the word round to this kanji, because it has both of these meanings. Both are right, and if you learn one that's better than not learning either, but maybe if you think about how round the coins themselves are inside this person's head, you'll remember this one too.

The arrow radical and the arrow kanji are the same. Sort of a "straight" shot to memorizing this kanji, you know?

- Hint: Just know your radicals and you'll know this kanji!

You lift the lid off a manhole and there's a towel with the name of a city on it.

- Hint: Picture this towel with the name of a city on it. Any city you like. Maybe it's your city!

The radical and the kanji for cow are exactly the same! That makes it easy to remember, so long as you know your radicals well enough.

- Hint: The radicals are important to know, so make sure you're studying them. They'll come back again, you know!

If you have seven swords, there's only so much you can do with them. The main thing? Probably using them to cut something.

- Hint: Take these seven swords and swing them around. Cut everything in your path, including yourself. Then, think about how dumb it was to try to use seven swords at once, and then feel the pain of the cut you gave yourself. Ouch, ouch ouch.

The radical and the kanji for direction are the same! Huzzah!

There is also another meaning too, though. This can also mean way as well. Think of it this way: When you move in one direction in your life, you are developing your own way. "The way of [your name here]."

- Hint: The only direction you need to go in is forward, it's always the right way.

The radical and the kanji for door are the same!

- Hint: Time to open the door to the reading part of this mnemonic.

You have a big guy here, with an extra drop of something below his thigh, hanging down. That's fat right there. He's so fat he has things of fat hanging off his fat.

- Hint: Maybe you should touch the fat below his leg just to see what it is... feel it, and squeeze it. It'll help you to remember that this kanji means "fat."

The radical and the kanji for father are the same.

- Hint: No, I am not your father... but this kanji / radical set is!

column4:
Few

,

A Little
column6:
You have a small slide. The thing about small slides is that they can only fit a few people at a time.

- Hint: Imagine a small slide (how could you not, after you see the radicals?) with only a few people on it, trying to move forward. Only a few people are required to create a slide traffic jam, though. :(

A narwhal sitting on a stool is your friend.

- Hint: Imagine that narwhal sitting there. It waves its flipper and says "hi friend" to you.

Fur and fur are the same as each other, so the meaning of this kanji should be simple. This can also mean hair, too, though more like furry hair.

- Hint: Just make sure you're studying your radicals, otherwise it won't be as simple as I'd hoped.

A triceratops is laying out to dry. But it's so big, and it's laying on its side, so only half of it gets dry.

- Hint: Imagine the triceratops on its side, then imagine it getting up. When it stands up normally, half of its body is soaking wet still. It's a half-n-half triceratops right now.

The radical heart and the kanji heart are the same. Rejoice and let your heart be free!

- Hint: Also, make sure you know the radicals by heart, it'll help you to learn more effectively, just like with this kanji.

There's a person inside your head.

- Hint: And, you have no idea how to get them out. They're inside for good, and it's freaking you out. As in, there's a little person in there, running around, controlling your brain. People think you're crazy, but you know better... He's inside there, doing evil things.

The life radical and the life kanji are the same, so hopefully you now just know them both.

- Hint: Study your radicals and you'll read good.

You have a private mouth that's a machine. But you have to keep your machine mouth private because it would scare all the non-machine people around you.

- Hint: Doesn't this kanji look like a machine mouth? Now wouldn't you want to keep that private from the people you know?

The sun lets out one drop, and then another drop. The drops dance together in the air, combine, and when they hit the ground, up sprouts your mother!

- Hint: Picture these two drops of the sun morphing before your very eyes until they look exactly like your dear ol' mum. She's bright and shining like the sun, and she's looking down at you, her big drop-eyes full of tears.

The slide is dry at noon. The sun is brightest at noon, so it dries the morning dew off the slide, making noon the perfect time to slide.

- Hint: Picture all the kids out sliding on the slide at noon during their lunch break. It's hot and dry and they're very happy.

Balance a spoon on your pointed fingers and it will always point north. The spoon is like a compass needle and your fingers guide the knowledge your body already has and uses it to point north. That's science, friends!

Notice how the fingers radical is a little different here? That's because you're pointing them really hard.

- Hint: Imagine taking a spoon and balancing it on your fingers. Now watch the spoon spin spin spin until it stops and ultimately points north.

The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for now first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means now as well.

- Hint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!

The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for old first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means old as well.

Note: This "old" does not refer to people. Think of it as "old things" instead.

- Hint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!

The origin radical and the origin kanji are the same!

- Hint: Know your radicals!

You're known to get the ailment evening toe, which is when your toe catches on fire after getting really, really hot (imagine this happening, ouch!). The only way to fix it is to cool your toe down, and the best way to do that is to go outside.

- Hint: After imagining your evening toe overheating, rush outside to fix it. It's the best way to prevent fire toe, which is way worse. In the evening it's nice and cold outside too, so feel this on your skin, and feel the cold air on your toe, which is starting to get some relief.

column4:
Part

,

Minute

,

Separate

,

Understand
column6:
The fins that fell onto my sword were sliced into two parts.

- Hint: The logic of this story makes a lot of sense - even in the kanji itself the fins are falling onto the sword from above. What happens to things that fall onto swords? They become more than one part.

You have fins in private. But, you want the world to see them, so you take them public.

- Hint: Picture yourself in private, with fins. You wish others could see them. "That's it," you decide. "It's time to show the world. I'm going to make my fins public!"

If you have a bow and a stick you need to pull the two back together to shoot it. If you can't pull it, you won't be shooting anything.

- Hint: Imagine taking a stick and pulling it back into your bow. Imagine how hard you have to pull. This thing is really strong!

The stop radical is the same as the stop kanji.

- Hint: Know your radicals, yo!

The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for task first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means task as well.

- Hint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!

You cut the leaf with your sword into ten thousand pieces!

- Hint: If you can get to ten thousand different pieces, then that means your sword is absolutely perfect. If your sword dulls before you get to ten thousand, you have to throw it away.

The canopy you use in private is very wide.

- Hint: You want your private canopy to be wide so you can sprawl out under it is as much as you want. No one's going to come in and tell you to close your legs or sit up straight. So it can be as wide as you like!

We have the winter radical and the two radical (though it's sort of slanted). What's two times the winter radical, if radicals are just a part of a kanji? Two times would be enough to create the entire kanji, which is also winter.

- Hint: You could also think, "Winter too" instead of "two." Because, this kanji is in fact "winter too."

The bamboo radical and the bamboo kanji are exactly the same!

- Hint: Just make sure you know your radicals!

The radical car and the kanji car are exactly the same.

- Hint: Make sure you study your radicals... though don't do it while driving.

If someone has a big head you have to try to focus on the center of it when you talk to them.

- Hint: You don't want to get caught with your eyes wandering all over their big head. Stare right at the center of their face. Ah geez, their eyes are kinda far away from here. You can really only see their nose...

The beggar is pointing his forehead up at you, his feet trapped in the ground. What diabolical scheme are you planning with this poor beggar you trapped? Turns out, you're planning to copy him to have your own version of him.

- Hint: You can imagine the whole story - him walking along, you setting a trap... and then whamo! You catch him. Then, come up with some crazy way / invention you're going to copy him. Are you cloning? Are you just taking his skin? Are you removing his forehead to grab his brain? Up to you - just make sure you make it ridiculous enough to remember.

The leader samurai didn't become leader by sitting around not taking action. He got to where he is by doing.

- Hint: Imagine the leader samurai doing things. He's doing more than anyone else, no one can keep up with what he's doing.

The ear radical and ear kanji are the same in looks as well as meaning.

- Hint: Study those radicals hard to make sure you know your kanji as well!

column4:
Early

,

Fast

,

Quick
column6:
When the sun is over the cross it's time to go to church... which is so darn early. And if you want to get to church early, you need to be fast, otherwise you'll be too late.

- Hint: Imagine the sun coming up slowly, over the horizon. It then lines up with the cross, and at that moment, your alarm goes off, waking you up. You check the alarm clock, and instead of displaying the time, it just says EARLY and FAST on it, flashing in big red letters and alternating.

You're looking for a treasure, but no normal treasure... a treasure that's a stash of energy. Not gold, money, or anything like that. Imagine yourself finding it, and opening up a treasure chest. Out bursts a spirit ball of energy like you've never seen.

- Hint: Try to touch the energy spirit, it's pretty amazing. Is it solid? Does it shock you? What does it feel like? Be sure to imagine it out.

If you want to dry your horns you need to lay them flat. If they aren't flat they'll always be a little damp somewhere and you'll never have a moment's peace.

- Hint: Imagine carefully taking off your horns and laying them flat on a paper towel. You have to smooth them out so they're as flat as possible.

A leader with a spoon is planting flowers so that one day this place may be full of beautiful flowers.

- Hint: It's kind of weird that the flowers radical is only a part of the flower kanji, but you'll make do. Just focus on the fact that the leader is planting all these flowers for a bigger picture thing (that's what leaders do). He wants there to be flowers for future generations as well, because he's a nice dude like that.

column4:
Foot

,

Leg

,

Sufficient
column6:
The radical for foot and the kanji for foot are exactly the same.

That being said, there's also another meaning you should keep in mind, which is sufficient. If you think about it, one foot should be sufficient enough to walk around with if you hop.

- Hint: Same kanjis and radicals make Jack a happy boy. You should also learn the other meaning as well, though, if you can.

Take your fingers to the street to hit some people! Street fingers are for curling into a fist. And that street fist wants to do some hitting!

- Hint: Imagine: it's just you, your fingers, and the wild street. It's hitting time!

There is a leaf growing out of the sun! You fly out into space to check it out and when you get closer you see that it isn't just one leaf, it's a hundred! That makes sense, you wouldn't be able to see just one leaf on the sun from where you were on earth.

- Hint: Imagine flying toward the sun to see a hundred leaves growing together in the shape of one big leaf. You want to go closer!

You have water already... and it's pretty cold. All it takes is one cold drop of liquid nitrogen added to it to turn it into one big block of ice, just like that.

- Hint: Go ahead and touch it... wow, it's really cold - and only from one drop, too. Feel the burn on your finger from where you touched the ice.

The insect radical and insect are the same in looks as well as and meaning.

- Hint: It's times like these when you gotta hope you're studying your radicals!

column4:
Letter

,

Character

,

Symbol
column6:
The roof child stands upon the roof, holding up a single letter, a single character, a single symbol for the world to see.

- Hint: More people can see this character since the kid is on the roof.

Rice paddy power comes from a man. One man, in fact. He's running on a big wheel next to the rice paddy and providing all of the power for the rice to grow and be harvested.

- Hint: Picture the power this man is generating! Now look at the next rice paddy and you'll see it's on a different power grid with a different man powering it.

The radical master and the kanji master have the same meanings!

This kanji also means main because the master is the main person of a dojo or household or business.

What is the evening mouth? Imagine a mouth that’s up in the night sky. It’s just there, talking, and only comes out at night. It only appears in one area of the world (what area would you choose? Imagine yourself going to that place to see the “night mouth.”), and appears only one month out of the year (more on this in a second). The “evening mouth” is the most famous thing in the _____ area (this is the area you choose). He’s so famous that everybody knows his name (“Evening Mouth.”).

- Hint: Imagine yourself going to the area you chose, and watching “Evening Mouth” speak. There are thousands of others there, wanting to see the giant floating mouth in the night sky. “Evening Mouth” then says “Everyone, what’s my name!?” and everyone shouts back “Evening Mouth!” in unison. “Evening Mouth” has certainly gotten really famous.

The radical not and the kanji not are the same thing! That makes it easy... Not!

- Hint: Actually, it does make it easy - the radicals make kanji wayyy easier, no?

There's a mouth in the ground (in our case, it's a hatch), and inside is some kind of prison you can't quite get to. If you've ever seen Lost, this will sound familiar... on the hatch, there's actually a series of numbers that you don't understand.

- Hint: What are these numbers? What do they mean? Think over it for a while, get frustrated, and try to figure it out. You can't, though, so you probably won't ever get inside.

The leader of alligators... she's no ordinary leader, that's for sure. She's not a politician.. she's not a queen... She's one of the Other Ones, a group of strange, eccentric people who become leaders of animals.

- Hint: Imagine different groups of leaders - they're all dressed nice and normal. Then, off to the side are the leaders who are leaders of bears, cats, alligators, and narwhals... they're the other ones, no matter how you look at it. They are in their own group, and they are considered "others" because society won't accept them :(

If someone tries to dig up private dirt on you, tell them no thanks, that stuff is in the past. Some things should stay in the past. Not everyone needs to know everything about your life and your past.

- Hint: Keep your private dirt in the past. It's better for everyone.

The plate kanji and the plate radical are exactly the same, like two matching pieces of china.

- Hint: If you know your radicals, you know your kanji too.

column4:
Previous

,

Ahead

,

Past

,

Former
column6:
Slide some dirt on your legs so you can feel like you're from a previous time. Everything from the past is in the dirt. Dead people, dinosaur bones, your mom's secrets in a box from her past life. All these things come back to you as you slide the dirt all over your legs.

- Hint: Imagine the feeling of dirt on your legs. Now think back to the previous day. The previous year. The previous century.

The radical for red and the kanji for red are the same thing!

- Hint: What a lucky ducky - as long as you know your radicals, you'll know this kanji's meaning as well!

The leader is next to the tree. What is he doing? He's leaning against it, resting.

- Hint: The best thing to do with a tree is rest under it. Picture the leader resting under the tree with his eyes half closed.

column4:
Say Humbly

,

Say

,

Humbly Say
column6:
There’s a cross in your mouth, so the things you say are very pious. Everything you say you say humbly.

- Hint: Imagine yourself with a cross in your mouth, saying all kinds of humble things. "Oh no, I'm not that good." "Oh no, my mustache doesn't look that great."

The radical see and the kanji see are exactly the same!

- Hint: Make sure you're studying your radicals. If you do, you'll know a lot of kanji as well, almost magically!

The shellfish radical and the shellfish kanji are the same! It can be just the shell part too.

- Hint: Shellfish are shellfish, you know?

The stone radical and stone kanji are the same thing!

- Hint: Know your radicals and therefore know your kanji. It's just that simple.

column4:
Substitute

,

Replace

,

Period

,

Age
column6:
The leader for the ceremony can't come so you need a substitute to replace them ASAP!

This kanji has another meaning too. The leader can't come to the ceremony because they forgot what period of time it was. If they think they're in the wrong age, they won't come because they're trying to lead some monkeys in the ceremony instead.

- Hint: Picture the leader of the ceremony out back, unsure of what period or age they're in, while the substitute leader walks in and stares at them in shock.

Always remember to give umbrellas to the spirits to show your thanks. The next time you're walking by a shrine and you see a statue dedicated to a spirit, leave your umbrella open to protect it. This is the best way you can show your thanks for life, food, shelter, and all that good, good stuff.

- Hint: Picture a spirit shrine with an umbrella protecting it from the heavy rain. "Thanks for everything," you say softly.

The thread radical and thread are the same in looks as well as in meaning.

- Hint: This is why it's good to make sure you know your radicals.

When you see both a rice paddy and a street in the same place, you have the makings of a whole town!

- Hint: Think about it, a single farm wouldn't need a whole street. Just paths would do. There is a street next to this rice paddy, so there must be other people, which makes this a town.

Under his roof, the king stares into a drop of water containing his greatest treasure. Just kidding, the king has way more treasure than that. The drop of water is just reflecting what's around him: mounds and mounds of treasure, stacked all the way up to the roof.

- Hint: Picture the treasure reflected in the drop of water. It's marvelous!

Someone’s taking measurements of the trees… Why is someone taking measurements of trees? These people are planning to take the trees and cut them down to make their village.

- Hint: There is a whole group of people out there who are measuring these trees. Imagine them asking each other “do you think this will be a good tree for our village center?” and other people nodding in agreement or disagreement as they measure.

The world radical and the world kanji are the same, but there is another really important meaning you need to know: generation.

Think of it this way: the world is just made up of many different generations of people, plants, and animals all getting along together.

- Hint: It's all these generational differences that make the world go 'round!

The cow part of this kanji is slightly altered, but I think you can see where it is. The gun looks just fine, though. Think back to a fake memory you have living on the farm. You have your gun, and you gotta use it on a cow (ruh roh). Once a year on New Year's, you have to go out and shoot one of the cows. It's only a yearly shooting, though, so at least there's that respite.

- Hint: You'll have to imagine yourself doing this to remember the meaning of the kanji. Focus on the thought that "okay... it's only once a year... I only have to do this once a year..."

column4:
Angle

,

Corner

,

Antler
column6:
Your task in prison is to bend things into different angles and then put them in the corner. No one will tell you why you're doing this, but you get a couple cents an hour to do it, so you aren't going to complain.

- Hint: Picture yourself sitting in a corner, bending pieces of metal and scrap to fit the angle of that corner.

column4:
Axe

,

Bread Loaf Counter
column6:
The axe radical and the axe kanji are exactly the same, with one minor difference. This kanji is also used as the bread loaf counter, probably because bread was so big and hard in the past that they had to use axes to slice them.

- Hint: Imagine you've gone back in time a good hundred years, and you're trying to count loaves of bread after each swing of your axe. Axes and bread loaves will become intertwined in your brain.

The blue radical and the blue kanji are exactly the same.

- Hint: Don't feel blue, you should know this kanji automagically!

The leader has a book all about the human body. Knowing about bodies is a privilege. One that only leaders get—it helps them control all their subjects, like you.

- Hint: Imagine looking down at your body and thinking, huh, I wonder what all that junk is? Oh well, I'm sure the leader has it all figured out in that book of hers.

The color radical and color are the same in looks as well as in meaning.

- Hint: Color me pink! This kanji's super easy if you know your radicals.

There's rice spread out all over the ground. This will cause the Predator to come because he loves kome (rice). Then once he's gone, the next Predator will come to eat.

- Hint: Also imagine everyone else coming to the rice next. When rice spills, people come from all around to line up and grab a handful of it to take home. Who's next? Come forward!

Plant a spirit in the dirt before you start your company and it will be successful. That's what all the great, old Japanese companies did back in the olden days. That's why companies like Mitsubishi have been around for hundreds of years. They planted a spirit in the dirt to help their company grow, and grow it did!

- Hint: Picture a young person way back in old-timey history times burying the spirit of one of their ancestors in the dirt. Now watch as an old-timey time lapse plays out in front of your eyes and a company is born!

column4:
Correct

,

Right

,

Success
column6:
There's a triceratops and a wolverine. What are they doing together? You'd think they'd fight, but they took their battle to another venue... they're competing in a game show! One of them answers a question, and the host says, "Success! You're correct!"

- Hint: Feel free to think through several questions and answers, but make sure they're all right, because that's what we're focusing on. Also make sure to focus on the triceratops and the wolverine themselves. You want to make sure that when you see these two radicals you automatically know they're playing in a game show, not doing anything else, like fighting or racing or something.

The treasures are in the mouth where there’s ice. How cryptic! You want to find the treasure, that’s for sure (treasure is great!). It is somewhere where there is ice, so maybe the arctic? What you are looking at is a diagram which will guide you there.

- Hint: Imagine looking at a diagram or map – and it has pictures of treasure in an area where ice is. This is where you will find the mystical treasure. This diagram will show the way. You're so excited that you found this map!

You see some windows... you have a gun. What do you think you're going to do with this gun? Of course, you're going to shoot the windows... every single one of them. Each and every one.

- Hint: Make a point to make sure you get every one, and don't miss any of them. Actually search around in your imagination for any more windows, because you want to stress it's important you hit each and every window with your gun.

column4:
Feather

,

Feathers

,

Wing

,

Wings
column6:
The feather radical and feather are the same in looks as well as in meaning.

- Hint: Have you been studying your radicals? If so, this'll be easy!

You have a tree and another tree. You basically have yourself a forest!

- Hint: Follow the logic of this one and you should be okay.

The go radical and the go kanji are exactly the same!

- Hint: If you know your radicals well enough (and you do), you'll know this kanji.

The gold radical and the gold kanji are the same!

- Hint: Just know your radicals and you'll be golden, so to speak.

You plant your flowers in the light of the sun in the shape of a cross, but it's too hot—the sun is too strong—and you end up with grass. Flowers can't grow in these conditions.

- Hint: Think of how disappointed you are. You wanted a beautiful cross of flowers, and now you just have a big overgrown patch of thick grass. It isn't even pretty green grass, it's a little brown and damaged from the sun.

The village you always think of first is your hometown.

- Hint: Why would you ever talk about the village where someone else was born? Answer: you wouldn't. Everything is always about you.

The leader's key is the key that makes all the other keys. It's sort of like the one ring to rule them all, the one ring to bind them... except with keys.

- Hint: Imagine the leader taking his key to open up a safe that has a button to make other keys for the underlings. No key is as great as this key, though.

column4:
Many

,

Much

,

Lots Of
column6:
How many evenings are there? There are many.

- Hint: If you accidentally think "a lot" or something similar, that's okay too. It's the basic meaning that counts, and all these things are pretty close, though eventually you want to get to the point where you know that this kanji does in fact mean many.

The meat radical and meat are the same in looks as well as in meaning.

- Hint: Study those radicals, and perhaps we'll eat some meat tonight.

The meet radical and the meet kanji are the same!

- Hint: Know your radicals, yo!

You put a lid on your father. But, he won't taste good alone, so you mix in some other ingredients. They mingle inside the pot with him.

- Hint: This may seem traumatic, but actually your father is surprisingly into it. Imagine him mixed in with all kinds of other things. It's important to note that this kanji is about things being mixed in, not so much about the action of mixing. That's another kanji.

Someone on a scooter has an axe, and they're getting near to you really fast! Oh no, they're so close now, you need to get out of here!

- Hint: Picture a scooter coming toward you in the dark. You see the gleam of the axe as it looms nearer and nearer.

column4:
Older Brother

,

Big Brother

,

Elder Brother
column6:
Who's someone who's just a mouth with legs? That's your know-it-all older brother, who won't shut up about anything.

- Hint: To help this mnemonic along, literally imagine your older brother as someone that's just a giant mouth with a pair of legs walking around. It talks and talks and talks, too, irritating you. Feel the irritation specifically at your older brother. He's older than you, so you can't beat him up... yet.

The radical for rain and the kanji for rain are the same thing.

- Hint: Make sure you know your radicals!

The rice radical and rice are the same in looks as well as in meaning. This also refers to "America," maybe because America is covered in rice or fields or something?

- Hint: Aren't radicals nice? They make things so much easier... if you've been studying them.

The radical run and the kanji run are exactly the same!

- Hint: Make sure you know your radicals!

There's a mustache on the ground. Upon closer inspection, you see that the mustache on the ground is exactly the same as yours!

- Hint: Pick up the mustache, hold it up next to your face in front of a mirror. It's unbelievable, but it's the same in every way, down to the last hair.

The say radical and the say kanji are the same!

- Hint: Know your radicals, yo!

The self radical and self are the same in looks as well as in meaning.

- Hint: Radicals have self. Kanji has self. Kanji and radicals can sometimes be the same thing... so do they really have "self"? Only way to find out is to study both of them hard!

column4:
Shape

,

Form

,

Appearance
column6:
You're walking at night when you discover a lantern covered entirely in hair, making it a very strange shape. In fact, this is a form you'd never expect a lantern to take.

- Hint: Picture all the different shapes this hairy lantern could take in your mind.

Slide down a branch and your skin will come off. Unlike what Tarzan will make you believe, you can't just slide around on branches, they're rough and painful and if you do it your skin will come sliding off and it will hurt.

- Hint: Imagine sliding down a slide made of a big, branch. The branch's bark digs into your skin and pulls it right off of your body.

Giving a roof legs is the kind of construction you do. You make it so a roof can be in the sky. In addition to meaning "sky", this kanji often means "empty". Think about it - there's nothing more empty than the sky!

- Hint: Think about it. If you give a roof legs, it goes even higher up. What's higher up? The sky is!

For some reason, you are standing on the sun. It's obviously very hot, but the thing you notice most is the sound of you burning up.

- Hint: Imagine a super loud sizzling sound, drowning everything else out. It's ridiculously loud, and hurts your ears more than the sun's heat hurts your skin.

column4:
Study

,

Learn

,

Learning
column6:
You have a wild viking child you have to take care of. He won't do anything but study, surprisingly. You can't get him to eat, use the bathroom, or anything else. He just wants to study.

- Hint: Of course, this isn't what you'd expect of a little viking child. It's the opposite. That's why it's so surprising! He loves to study!

You see a triceratops in the distance. But, it's odd. It's perfectly pi shaped (that is, circular). Some kind of piceratops, if you will. The reason they are this shape is because they want to absorb as much sunlight (or just light is fine, too) as possible. They evolved to be round so they don't have any corners casting a shadow.

- Hint: Absorbing sunlight is natural for reptiles, after all. And a round one can absorb even more light. Imagine it sitting in a round spot of sun, enjoying the warmth. What a rare sight you've come across!

In a coffin is someone begging. But, it won't work. You won't listen. So, the man in the coffin just begins to think: What could I have done better in my life? Why am I in this situation? How will I get out? Think, damnit, think!!

- Hint: Imagine him changing from a begging position to a stereotypical "thinking" position, hand on chin, eyebrows furrowed. Focus on the beggar's thinking. This is a pretty abstract idea to imagine, so it will be important to create a very vivid picture in your mind's eye.

There's a mouth inside a mouth. But if you look even closer (not actually, but we're pretending), you can see another mouth inside that mouth... and another one inside of that one! It keeps going and going. Can you count the number of times there's a mouth inside a mouth? This kanji also means revolve too. Think of each "time" a thing happens, it loops back around and comes back to the beginning, revolving around again another time.

- Hint: Imagine yourself counting and counting smaller and smaller mouths inside of each other, recording the number of times you can find a mouth inside another mouth. Dig deeper and deeper until it feels ridiculous how small the mouths are getting. Be sure to focus on the counting and the number of times you find one. Now, how many mouths is this times two, because your mouth is like this too.

There's a hat decorated with fins and (presumably fish) mouths on it. Who wears strange hats like this? Turns out, the valley people are the ones who wear these. I'm talking about the "Valley Girls" of California, Hollywood / LA. They're into the crazy fashion, and they'll wear anything if it's deemed "cool" or something like that.

- Hint: Imagine a bunch of Valley Girls walking around with these strange hats. Fins and fish mouths... what a strange new fad.

You have a samurai with a flag on a stick. On his flag is this symbol, the kanji for voice. Why does he have that there? He feels like his Shogun isn't giving him and his fellow Samurai a voice, so he's brought a flag with the word "voice" written on it to protest.

- Hint: Imagine him and other samurai with their flags on sticks waving them around shouting things like "we want a voice in politics!" etc., etc.

The west radical and the west kanji are the same. Isn't that nice?

- Hint: Make sure you know all those radicals, will make your life more pleasant.

Our leader has a lip ring. Wait, our leader has a lip ring? WHAT??

- Hint: Think of our president (or your prime minister, or dictator, or whatever) and imagine this person appearing on television one morning with a big ol' lip ring. Feel surprised by it. Just say "What??" over and over again. You want to have the feeling of "what" in you when you imagine this - that'll help you to remember this kanji's meaning.

column4:
Wheat

,

Barley

,

Oats
column6:
The life radical is without the slide (as it sometimes is), but when you combine that with the winter radical, you have life during winter. What gives you life during the winter? It's the wheat you store away.

- Hint: Imagine you're starving. It's cold and you've run out of food. You don't know what you're going to do. If you don't find something, you'll lose your life. Then, you break open a barrel, and wheat pours out. It's beautiful. You just found some life in the middle of winter.

column4:
Younger Brother

,

Little Brother
column6:
There is someone with a bow and a stick, wearing horns, going down a slide. What type of person do you imagine? I'd say someone who's an immature boy. That would be your younger brother.

- Hint: Just pretend you have a younger brother for now, even if you don't. Also be sure to imagine this person really vividly. He is a stereotypical little boy, playing dress up with horns and a bow and stick (he can't have an arrow, that's dangerous), and he's going down a slide too.

Kings with hats. Did you know that all kings wear hats?

- Hint: Think of as many kings as you can think of. Guess what, every single one of them (aka all of them) wear hats! Think of strange hats, funny hats, and normal hats. Just make sure you're amazed by the fact they all are wearing them.

column4:
Behind

,

After

,

Back

,

Later
column6:
If you loiter around to poop in winter you never know what could be happening behind you. After you're done you could turn back to see something really crazy that you missed because you took so long to poop in the cold.

- Hint: Imagine trying to loiter while you poop in the winter. You're just trying to take your time as you squat over the snow, but soon you hear things behind you.

The blood radical and blood are the same in looks as well as in meaning.

- Hint: There'll be some bad blood between us if you're not studying your radicals, especially when they're the same like this kanji!

Under the ground, which you dug into, you found two great finds. You found both a mountain and a head, two strange things to find underground.

- Hint: You'll want to focus on the part where you find both, not so much the things themselves. Think about how you can't believe you did so well finding both things at once. Usually you only find one or the other when you're searching.

The sun AND the moon are out? With both their light-powers combined, it's incredibly bright outside.

- Hint: Look up at both of them, hanging out in the sky together. Make them super bright, so bright you have to shield your eyes.

There is a lid covering all the mouths that are too small to feed themselves, forming the capital. All of the small mouths come together and create a place where everyone can support each other.

- Hint: Picture the capital of your country. How many mouths have come together to support each other there? A thousand? A million? More?!

A leader with a spoon is a powerful thing. Even something like a spoon when given to the right man or woman can make great change in the world.

- Hint: Imagine your leader-hero holding a spoon out, then doing something awesome with it to totally change everything for the better. It's amazing the change this person can do with such a blunt, small, device!

The mouth of the king extends all the way around him (like in this kanji). Where his mouth reaches, that is his country, give or take a few drops.

- Hint: Imagine his talking taking physical form. As he talks, waves extend out from him, and stop right at the border of his country before getting to the next one.

column4:
Course

,

Science

,

Department
column6:
You scoop some grains into a ladle to do science. You're doing experiments on these grains in your science course.

- Hint: Imagine carefully ladling grains into different piles so you can do science experiments on them. This course is going to make you an expert. You'll be the best in this department!

If the yakuza hands you a spoon, death is coming for you. It's the death spoon, a sign that the yakuza is coming to cause your death.

- Hint: This spoon isn't for pudding, it's for death!

The radical death and the kanji death are the same.

- Hint: This thing is deceased. It ain't alive anymore.

column4:
Drawing

,

Picture

,

Painting
column6:
There's a close-up of a leaf in a rice paddy inside of a box. Wait, it's not a box, this whole thing is just a drawing.

- Hint: Look closely at this box-shaped drawing. See each little stroke, smell the paper and the lead.

column4:
Earth

,

Ground

,

Land
column6:
A dirt alligator lives in the earth, not the water. They can swim through the earth itself! Which is pretty scary.

You can think of this word as ground too, because that's kind of what earth is made of.

- Hint: Imagine seeing the earth moving as a dirt alligator rises out from the ground. You should run.

Behind that tree the sun is rising in the east. The sun always rises in the east, so if you head that way, past the tree, you'll be going east too.

- Hint: Picture the sun behind the tree, don't picture the sun alone, you'll burn your eyes. It's slowly coming up behind it. Now think: where does the sun rise? In the east!

The radical for eat and the kanji for eat are the same! Lucky you.

- Hint: If you know the radical, you basically know the meaning(s) of this kanji. There is a second meaning added to it, though, and that is meal. Just think about the things you eat? What are they? In the simplest form, they are just meals. So, if you know "eat" you should be able to remember "meal" as well.

You accidentally stab your cross into the eye of a lion. This is a terrible thing you did and you need to fix it right now. I'll be direct with you, this is something you have to fix on your own.

- Hint: How will you fix this mistake though? Maybe if you build a time machine you can go back and stop yourself from throwing your cross around so carelessly. Whatever you do, focus on how important it is to fix the mistake, more than anything.

There are some horns on the ground and a moon knife in front of you. When you try to move, they always rotate around with you, staying right in front. You can't escape these objects, for some reason.

This kanji means before too. Something that's in front of you is before you, after all.

- Hint: Perhaps it's some kind of magic, but you don't care. Why are these strange objects always in front of me? Why won't they stay put? This will get pretty freaky after a while. Try to run. Try to hide. Spin around. Do whatever you need to do. No matter what, these objects are always in front.

A narwhal and a moon is all you have. Imagine one of each under your arms.

- Hint: You don't have anything else. This is it. All you have.

Your private grains are meant to stay private! You shouldn't be sharing them with the whole town, they're just for you.

This kanji also means I. Why? Because what's more private than you? I mean, I! Basically, some things are only the business of you (I) and those things should be private.

- Hint: Look at your private grains. Who are those for? Why, they're for I!

Just before saying something important, you take an arrow to the mouth which seals your lips together, making it so you can't talk. Someone doesn't want you to share what you know with someone else.

- Hint: Imagine being so surprised by this arrow. Then, think of all the things you know that need to be said and told to everyone. Maybe you have information about nuke codes. Maybe you have information that will save the President. Whatever it is, make sure you know important things that need to be said (but also things that people want to prevent you from saying, even if it means shooting you in the mouth with an arrow).

A tsunami of tongues is coming at you. As it washes over you, you feel each individual tongue moving around on your body, licking you. They make you feel so... lively!

- Hint: Your entire body wakes up, you feel so lively! The tongues are making you more aware of yourself and your surroundings than you've ever been. You want to dance, you want to sing, you want to live your life.

The long radical and the long kanji are the same!

This kanji also means leader, because the longer a person is, the better a leader they'll be. Or maybe it was... the longer they've been somewhere? Whatever, longness = leaderness, you know?

- Hint: As long as you know the radical long, you know the kanji long as well.

Twenty mouths are together. That's a lot of mouths. What do they do? They sing beautiful music together.

- Hint: Listen to the twenty mouths. They sound great. Have them sing your favorite music. Also note that this kanji also means "bend." Imagine the music coming out at you bending all around in strange shapes through the air.
The radical <radical>neck</radical> and the kanji <kanji>neck</kanji> are exactly the same!

You lack ice. So you go to the store and see if they have any. Nope, no ice. So, now you go to the next store. Is there ice here? Nope. Next!

- Hint: Feel a little frustrated you can't find ice. Have the words "next next next" echoing through your head as you go from store to store, irritated.

A leader is wearing a lid and is standing outside in winter. Plus it's raining and she's covered in drops of water. On top of all this, it's night.

- Hint: If it helps, you can come up with a reason why she's outside in the winter at night. Also, why is she wearing a lid on her head? Probably because she's protecting her people from something that comes at night.

column4:
Older Sister

,

Big Sister

,

Elder Sister
column6:
The only woman in this city is your older sister. She's the only woman surrounded by a bunch of men, but she's following her dreams in the big city.

- Hint: You want to go to the city someday, but you're not old enough yet, like your older sister is.

column4:
Point

,

Decimal

,

Decimal Point
column6:
Your fortune boils down to a single point in time. One decimal point in the math of time determines how the rest of your future will go.

- Hint: Imagine actually going somewhere to get your fortune told and watching a big boiling pot of goo. As it boils, it melts down to a single point at the very bottom. Where this point is determines your future.

With a roof over her head, a woman can relax. She doesn't have to worry about rain or snow or finding a safe place to sleep. The roof also happened to be super cheap, so she can even relax about her finances.

- Hint: Picture the super relaxed woman lounging under her cheap but sturdy roof. Ah, she doesn't have a care in the world!

On the dirt you've made a roof over the ground where you can be in private. This is your room! That's really all a room is, you know? A covered, private place where you can have some time to yourself.

- Hint: Imagine the room you live in now. Take away all the stuff and you're left with a roof and the dirt on the ground. It's your own little private place.

A tsunami is coming, so you point your gun out the window at it. "You better turn back, sea, or I'll shoot!"

- Hint: You'll have to think of the "sea" as its own entity, controlling the tsunami, otherwise you might confuse and combine the two. So when you point your gun out the window, aim it at the "sea," not the "tsunami." It's like aiming for the head of a zombie and not the arms or legs.

The sheep radical and the sheep kanji are the same in looks as well in meaning.

- Hint: You are no sheep—you study your radicals, unlike most Japanese learners. You'll learn sooo much faster!

A long time ago, someone put up a canopy over their fortune telling booth and created the first shop. This store was fortune-based, but since then lots of different stores have popped up!

- Hint: Picture the very first store in history. A fortune teller decided enough was enough, they should be in some kind of structure where it's safe, official looking, and more permanent.

The cross you're holding above your head to keep your horns dry keeps pulling you south. Probably because it's warmer and less damp down south.

- Hint: Look down and see the compass pointing south and feel the cross pulling you in that direction.

The sun that gives life is our very own star (which we happen to call the sun). Of course, all the other stars are probably giving life to other planets as well.

- Hint: Imagine all sorts of stars all around the universe giving life to planets as suns. These are all the stars you see in the sky and there are billions of them. I hope you don't feel overwhelmed by how minuscule we really are when you look up at all of them.

column4:
State

,

Province

,

County
column6:
Think about Japan. Japan is a country made up of islands. They're basically three drop drop drops in the large river that is the Pacific Ocean. These are Japan's states or provinces.

- Hint: Also, another way to think of this is that the river radical is actually just three rivers, separating drops, which are capitals of various states. Rivers are usually great ways to divide up a country, and states are one way to do it!

You come across an angel wearing a hat that's covered in flowers. So, you do the only natural thing. You take this angel, chop him up into tiny pieces, and dry him out. Then, you make tea out of all the dried up angel bits. You wear the hat, though.

- Hint: How does this angel-flower tea taste? Be sure to imagine it. Probably heavenly *rimshot.*

In a rice paddy you find a heart and it makes you think. You think a lot of thoughts like, "Whose heart is this? Why is it in a rice paddy? Why am I thinking out loud?"

- Hint: Think, think, think. Think about this rice paddy heart.

You stop at a small slide. What were you doing before you stopped here? You were walking.

- Hint: Question is, what made you stop? Imagine yourself walking at a nice casual pace... then imagine something that would make you stop that's incredibly interesting and strange. Maybe an alien is going down the slide? He would say "keep walking, friend."

A drop hits your mustache. Where did it come from? "Ah, it came from yonder," you say, facing that way.

- Hint: Yonder is a bit of a weird word, but it fits the meaning of this kanji quite well. You'll have to trust me that it's more useful in Japanese than it is in English. When you imagine through this mnemonic, make sure the drop comes from the side and hits you in the mustache with quite a bit of force. That means it came from a far distance thus making you look over "yonder."

column4:
Younger Sister

,

Little Sister
column6:
Who's that woman pretending to be a jet? That's my younger sister. *Sigh*

- Hint: Imagine a little girl (your younger sister) running around with her arms out, pretending to be a jet, too. Prwoooooo!

While riding your scooter, you take your sword and cut out an area on the ground. This whole place is your area now!

- Hint: Imagine riding your scooter around in a really large circle, pressing your sword into the ground as you do. Once you close the circle, you claim to everyone around that this is YOUR area, and they aren't allowed in.

You have to take the measurement of a leader. Imagine yourself measuring that leader's height and then coming up short. This is not good, you think. Leaders need to be at least six feet tall. So, to make the leader tall enough, you attach another head to the top of the leader's head.

- Hint: Make sure you really feel like the person can’t be a leader because they’re too short when you measure them (I know this isn’t true, but we’re remembering kanji here, anything goes!). As long as you feel disconcerted that the leader isn’t tall enough, you should be able to remember that you need to attach something to the leader to make them tall enough. The fact that you’re attaching another head to the top of the leader's head is pretty weird too, and should help you to remember the meaning.

column4:
Bill

,

Tag

,

Label

,

Note
column6:
The tree has an umbrella, and it's holding it over his head, which is strange, because trees normally like water... turns out, it's not water falling on him, but dollar bills floating down.

- Hint: The sick part of this is that those dollar bills were once this tree's friends. The tree is sobbing uncontrollably as pieces of his friends fall on him and all around him - which is why he's using the umbrella to protect himself.

The bird radical and the bird kanji are the same!

- Hint: As long as you know the radical bird you know the kanji bird.
The radical <radical>black</radical> and the kanji <kanji>black</kanji> are exactly the same.

column4:
Boat

,

Ship

,

Vessel
column6:
Your boat has fins and a mouth! It's still a boat though.

- Hint: Picture this boat. It's still a boat, but there is a big mouth on the front and it has fins that it paddles forward with.

The slide coming out of the patient's heart is there because a mad scientist is testing to see if it's a good way to drain the body of blood. The patient is alive now... but they are definitely slated for certain death.

- Hint: As you imagine the mad scientist drawing blood out of the patient's heart with a small slide, also imagine a little meter hooked up to him as well. On one end is "SURVIVE!" on the other end is "CERTAIN DEATH." Right now the finger is pointing close to certain death, though :(

This kanji uses a modified jet radical. The front area of the wing is wider than the middle area of the wing. This may seem counterintuitive, but by doing this they can fit so much more jet fuel. The jet zooms off and keeps going for a long, long time, until it reaches the end of the earth.

- Hint: Imagine the end of the earth being like how they imagined it pre-Columbus era. Just a big drop going off into space, giant waterfalls plummeting down. Your crazy jet has made it to the very end! Congratulations!

column4:
Family Name

,

Last Name

,

Surname
column6:
Your clan is where you get your name. But not your given name, your family name. That's why people have names that mean "in a rice paddy" and "near the ferry crossing." The location of your clan determined your surname! Hope your ancestors didn't live on "Poo Lake" or something.

- Hint: Think about your own surname in your language. Where did it come from? Were you a clan of village dwellers? Maybe you made shoes! You should look it up and find out!

That slide is your husband's only fault. He loves that slide, more than you, and it's the only thing you don't like about him.

- Hint: Imagine looking out the window of your house and watching your husband slide down his slide over and over. He's not even good at it, he falls off the side halfway down most of the time. You want to complain, but he's pretty decent otherwise. This is his only fault.

The radical fish and the kanji fish are exactly the same!

- Hint: Nothing fishy about that, right?

column4:
From

,

Since

,

Compared With

,

With

,

By Means Of
column6:
The lion drops a drop of saliva onto this person from above. The person is in a much worse place compared with where they were before, since they only just recently fell into this pit.

- Hint: Picture the person, the lion is leaning over them, the drop of spit dangling from their mouth. "I-I want to go back where I came from," the person gasps, shaking.

column4:
Group

,

Association

,

Team
column6:
Sew thread through your top hat and to the top hats of other people you know and you'll turn into a group of top hat wearing people. You're all connected by the thread now, so everyone will assume you're a group, even if that's all you guys have going for yourselves.

- Hint: Picture a group of people threaded together by their top hats. Don't you want to be part of a cool group like that? Your own top hat team.

Under this roof is a pig. Your pig, because it's your house! You keep your pig inside where it's nice and warm. He's a member of your family, so he deserves to live in your home too.

- Hint: Picture the little pig, prancing around happily under the roof of your house.

This kanji is the same as the radical it comes from. Lack becomes Lack!

- Hint: If you know the radical you know this.

You're flying in a Jet. Even though it's one of the fastest things on earth, your child is sitting in the back asking, "Are we there yet? Are we there yet?" You have to keep responding. "Not yet! Not yet! NOT YET!"

- Hint: Feel the irritation of this. How irritating is this kid going to be the whole flight over? The jet is going as fast as it can!

The thread that ties you to your clan is paper. Your papers, that is.

- Hint: The paper itself was also made by your clan using thread woven really tightly together.

There's a scooter with your mama carrying a task she needs to get done. You see her pass through, hurrying by to get that task done.

- Hint: Imagine your mama passing through your house on a scooter, not stopping because she needs to get her task done urgently.

column4:
Peoples

,

People

,

Nation
column6:
The mouth clan are a group of people. They are the people of a nation.

- Hint: The mouth clan are distinct peoples. They do, of course, use their mouths.

A giant cross with a mouth stands above you. "I am reason!" it says to you. It is the Cross of Reason.

- Hint: Because it's a cross with a mouth, it thinks that it is reason in all the chaos.

The king's village is the reason he's king. Without the village there would be no reason to have a king in the first place.

- Hint: If a king has no one to rule then he has no reason to exist.

Next to the tree, a lid is put on your father. "Hello child," he says. "This is your new school."

- Hint: He goes on to explain that he changed your school to here because there is a tree to block the satellite's view. Also, he wears a tin foil lid on his head so they can't track him. The regular school was no good because "they were watching." So now you have this new school, taught under a tree by your father who's wearing a lid on his head.

The rain is hated so much by wolverines, so they always want to live in the snow.

- Hint: Imagine rain falling on a wolverine and how much they hate it, so the wolverine moves up north to somewhere with lots of snow.

You have a private bow made of insects that's extremely strong. Insect bodies are really durable, so they make for strong bows. You also have to be strong to use it, since it was made just for strong arms.

- Hint: Imagine holding this strong bow in your strong arms. Look closer at the little insect bodies that make it up. Thanks for your help, little guys.

The eye leaf grows only in the winter. Every other leaf, however, will do the opposite, which is to grow in the summer.

- Hint: Just think of the eye leaf as weird (it is weird, after all). It grows in the winter. Now, think of any normal leaves. They do the exact opposite, which is to grow in the summer.

column4:
Tall

,

Expensive

,

High
column6:
There's a lid on your mouth and mustache, covering up all your talking holes. This is because you kept saying how tall and expensive you are.

- Hint: Imagine yourself saying how tall and expensive you are to everyone in the room. Then they use a lid to cover your mouth so you can't talk to anyone anymore. But, then your mustache starts talking, saying the same thing. That's why this lid covers both your mustache and your mouth. Now you can't say that you are tall or expensive.

A teacher in winter is happiest because they get to teach! The kids can't go out and play because it's too cold. They all have to come in and stay warm as the teacher teaches!

- Hint: Picture a teacher excitedly teaching, bundled up in the cold. Snow falling outside. Grumpy children being taught inside.

column4:
Time

,

O'clock

,

Hour
column6:
The sun is used in a temple to tell time. They don't have clocks or cell phones, they have sun dials and good old fashioned "looking up and seeing where the sun is right now."

This also can mean o' clock, as in "five o'clock" It's used when measuring what time it is in Japanese.

- Hint: Imagine being in a temple and realizing you don't know what time it is. Never fear! Look on up at the sun. Ah, yes. Blinding noon.

You have two bows but they're both covered in ice. This has made them very weak.

- Hint: Just look at these weak, iced over bows. If you tried to draw back their strings they'd snap into a million pieces.

Use a scooter to travel the circumference of the world and it will take you a full week. Seven whole days!

- Hint: A week in earth time is also known as a "full scoot" in scooter lingo. ;)

There is an insect sliding around under your table, being blown by the wind. You try to grab the insect but it keeps sliding past your hand because the wind is so strong. It’s going to start blowing you around under the table too!

- Hint: Picture an insect, on its back, being blown around under a table. Feel the wind pushing you as you try to save the poor thing.

- Hint: This kanji also means style too. You can think of the wind blowing one style in fashion one moment and then another the next. It blows your clothes off and blows new style clothes onto you, over and over again. Imagine this happening. Are you embarrassed when all the clothes are off? Pleased when you get new style clothes on?

column4:
Write Down

,

Record
column6:
What you say to oneself (yourself), you decide to write down. Whether this is in the form of a journal, diary, or blog, you feel the need to record these important thoughts in some way.

- Hint: Just imagine writing in a diary and saying everything to write aloud to yourself in your head.

- Hint: "Dear me, today I learned a lot of new kanji on WaniKani. It was the best. I love the crabigator sooooo much. Love, me."
The radical <radical>yellow</radical> and the kanji <kanji>yellow</kanji> are exactly the same!

column4:
Answer

,

Response

,

Reply
column6:
"Does the bamboo shirt suit me?" you ask... but nobody will answer.

- Hint: Shout "PLEASE ANSWER ME!" a few times to get the idea of "answer" in your head. What you really want is an answer, whether it's bad or good, but nobody's willing to say anything because you look so terrible.

The stool is in the cliff. If someone has a stool deep inside a cliff, they are most likely pretty anti society, hiding away like that.

- Hint: Imagine someone who looks super antisocial (and a little feral). Ask them why they're sitting on this stool inside a cliff... they reply because they hate people. They are anti people!

A wolverine is going down a slide into your mouth. Why is he going into your mouth, though? You're opening it really wide, because you're screaming "BUDDY!!! You're so excited to see your wolverine buddy-pal again. You thought he was dead.

- Hint: Make sure you feel super happy. Even yell "Buddy" out loud while imagining this wolverine coming at you, if you're not in a quiet-zone.

Your nation's flag sits on top of a caped mouth. This is the symbol for the "Bureau of Secret Things." It's a special department of your government made to keep things hidden.

- Hint: The cape covering the mouth represents how this bureau never talks about their secrets. The flag represents your country. Think about all the cool secret things the Bureau of Secret Things must have.

There are some shellfish in a net that you can buy. You can't just buy loose shellfish. You can only buy the ones that are in the net, bagged up and ready for your money.

- Hint: Imagine looking over a bunch of different kinds of shellfish wrapped in nets. Think about which ones you want to buy.

A rain cloud is still a cloud! It's probably going to rain on you soon though, so I hope you have a jacket or an umbrella.

- Hint: Picture all of the different types of clouds in the sky. There are puffy white ones, heavy dark ones, and wispy thin ones. But they're all clouds.

column4:
Comfort

,

Ease

,

Pleasure
column6:
The white ice tree is a magical tree. When you eat its ice flowers it gives you incredible amounts of comfort, ease, and pleasure.

- Hint: Imagine yourself picking the white ice flowers off the tree. Then, put it in your mouth. Make it taste comforting... It puts you at ease. Then, swallow it. Feel your head go nuts with comfort. This is the greatest drug in the world when it comes to comfort. So much pleasure!

column4:
Count

,

Number

,

Amount
column6:
In the winter, the woman has to go through all the rice and count each individual grain. Once she's counted all of them, she'll have an amount / number so that she can split them up accordingly.

- Hint: She has to count each grain out in order to divvy up the supply to last through the winter. Imagine yourself getting just a few grains today for food. It's not a good time for you guys :(

You have at your disposal a tsunami and a hook to assassinate this person. Which weapon will you choose. Decide now!

- Hint: Have trouble with the decision. Which one? Tsunami will be big and cool, but a hook will be more discreet. How can you decide? Can you think of a neat way to decide this, like Two-Face on Batman?

Using just thread meeting the paper (with a little ink on the end) you create a masterpiece of a drawing (or a painting).

- Hint: It's unbelievable the kind of drawing you're able to draw with just the tip of a thread. So much detail. So artistic. If it helps, imagine that you drew the Mona Lisa, better than the original, only using this floppy thread tool.

column4:
Dwelling

,

Reside

,

Dwell
column6:
The leader of the masters gets the biggest dwelling. She resides in a huge mansion on the top of the mountain, surrounded by all the other masters in their smaller dwellings.

- Hint: Picture the leader master's big, beautiful dwelling. Everyone else is jealous.
